Peggy had been wanting to see Mount Rushmore since grade school. Today was the day she finally got to see it. The ongoing Crazy Horse monument is pretty close to Mt Rushmore, so we visited there next. Did you know the construction of this is privately funded? Here is a model of the sculpture

Devil's Tower Legend There are several versions of this legend, but the go something like this. According to a Kiowa legend, eight children once played here. One was mysteriously transformed into a bear. His seven sisters fled in fear across the eroded plains of northeastern Wyoming to a giant tree stump, which rose from the ground even as they tried to climb it. Clawing furiously, the bear tried to reach the girls but could not. The stump then turned to stone, preserving the giant gouges from the bear's claws. The sisters floated into the heavens, where they can be seen at night as seven bright stars. There is quite a large parrie dog community around the tower. Peggy had quite a good time watching these crazy little guys. We spen the night in Deadwood, SD. Rudy you'll be happy to know that local historians applaude the creators of Deadwood HBO for it's accuarcy. Also, did you know all the main characters were real people in Deadwood? Okay, everybody just settle down. I know you've been waiting for this report. Peggy assures me this was just fabulous. We got to Ralston just in time to see the mule parade. As soon as I finish this post Peggy and I head on to Yellowstone. We are in Bozeman, Montana right now at a Kinko's Copy center. We had a greta day in Bannack State park, Nevada City, and Virginia City All forming gold mining towns. There has been a lot of questions about the animals in the Tripple D posts. This animals are still very wild. They can be handled by their handler, but he has the utmost respect for them. It's not like they train them to sit and beg or something like that, but they are trained enough so that they to have some respect for the handeler. Then they take the animals out to some natural setting and turn them lose basically. I was standing in front of a 3 feet high chicken wire fence when I shot that Tiger. Pretty exciting really. Peggy is seeing lots of mules and is looking forward to mule days on Saturday. Well I better hit the road. Thanks to whoever took the time to help Wilbur look at this blog. Well, I finally got somewhere that I can log on and update this, although no pictures yet. I am in East Glacier, Montana. I spent about 4 hours in the park this afternoon. It was kinda of wet and gloomy, but I went on a couple of hikes and took a few pictures anyway. It is very beautiful here as one would expect. I have driven about 2300 miles since I left Fremont last Friday. I met another guy from Michigan here today that took highway 2 out here also. He sumed up the eastern 3/4's of this state in this manner, "I hate Montana. I don't ever want to see another blade of grass... ever." Now I know where all that certified Black Angus Beef comes from, and yes unlike like my friend I just mentioned, I will eat it again. Bob, there are mexican resturants galore out here, so travel without fear. About the most interesting thing that happened on the way out here was in Wisconson. A bald eagle swooped down right beside the Jeep and grabbed up a mouse or some other rodent that was having a bad day. I also seen the grill that cooked the world's largest hamburger, and drove through the geographical center of North America. Don't worry, I have pictures! Tommorrow I move to my "permanent" spot, at least for a week. Hopefully I can find some internet hookup and upload some pictures. See ya.
